constructs.name: Novelty_Seeking_Trait
constructs.description: Stable personality tendency to seek stimulation, variety, and new experiences

constructs.name: Work_Role_Fragmentation
constructs.description: Degree to which job/role requires attending to multiple distinct responsibilities and domains

constructs.name: Context_Switching_Frequency
constructs.description: How often one makes unplanned switches between tasks, apps, or attentional targets

constructs.name: Sleep_Quality
constructs.description: Restorative quality of sleep the previous night

constructs.name: General_Stress_Level
constructs.description: Overall psychological stress and pressure experienced

constructs.name: Cognitive_Fatigue
constructs.description: Mental tiredness and depleted cognitive resources

constructs.name: Self_Regulation_Capacity
constructs.description: Available capacity to control impulses and regulate behavior

constructs.name: Perceived_Task_Overwhelm
constructs.description: Feeling of having too much to do and being unable to manage it all

constructs.name: Switching_Habit_Strength
constructs.description: Automaticity and strength of habitual context-switching behavior patterns

constructs.name: Task_Engagement_Level
constructs.description: Degree of absorption, focus, and involvement in the current task

constructs.name: Task_Aversiveness
constructs.description: How unpleasant, difficult, or unappealing current tasks feel

constructs.name: Boredom_Understimulation
constructs.description: Feeling understimulated, lacking interest, or insufficiently engaged

constructs.name: Anxious_Restlessness
constructs.description: Jittery anxiety, inability to sit still, urge to do something else

constructs.name: Task_Clarity
constructs.description: Knowing clearly what to do next and how to proceed with work

constructs.name: Notification_Interruption_Load
constructs.description: Amount of external notifications, pings, and interruptions received

constructs.name: Digital_Environment_Friction
constructs.description: Barriers and friction built into digital environment that make switching harder

edges.description: Higher task engagement reduces the pull toward switching contexts
Greater self-regulation allows resisting impulses to switch
Stronger habits make switching more automatic and frequent
Restless anxiety drives seeking relief through switching
Boredom drives seeking novelty through switching
More notifications trigger more context switches
Higher friction makes switching more effortful and less frequent
Higher novelty-seeking increases baseline tendency toward switching
More aversive tasks increase escape-motivated switching
Higher stress impairs sleep quality
Overstimulation from switching disrupts sleep restoration
Poor sleep increases stress reactivity and baseline stress
Feeling overwhelmed directly increases stress
Fragmented roles with multiple demands create ongoing stress
Poor sleep leads to starting the day already fatigued
Chronic stress depletes cognitive resources
Frequent switching is cognitively expensive and depleting
Low physical energy contributes to mental fatigue
Good sleep restores self-regulation resources
Mental fatigue depletes self-regulation capacity
Physical energy supports self-regulation efforts
Stress depletes self-regulation resources
Fragmented roles with many domains create overwhelm
Switching prevents task completion, accumulating unfinished work
Good sleep restores physical energy
Each switching episode reinforces and strengthens the habit
Clear understanding of what to do enables deeper engagement
Aversive tasks reduce willingness to engage
Mental fatigue impairs ability to engage deeply
Physical energy supports sustained engagement
Boredom reflects and causes disengagement from tasks
Restless state interferes with focused engagement
When tired, tasks feel more difficult and aversive
Stress magnifies negative perception of tasks
Overwhelm makes individual tasks feel more daunting
Unclear tasks feel more aversive due to uncertainty
High novelty seekers are more prone to boredom
Clear tasks provide direction that reduces boredom
Tedious aversive tasks create boredom
Stress manifests as anxious, restless state
Overwhelm creates anxiety and restless urge to act
Constant notifications create vigilant, restless state
Poor sleep increases anxiety reactivity
Fatigue reduces emotional regulation, increasing restlessness
Mental fatigue impairs clear thinking about tasks
Overwhelm clouds judgment about what to prioritize
Higher friction environments reduce notification exposure
Self-regulation enables proactive environment design

indicators.name: topic_switch_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the number of times the browsing topic changes substantially. A topic switch occurs when a search or visit is about a clearly different subject from the previous 2-3 activities. Example: 'ketamine research' to 'mobile phone plans' = 1 switch. 'ketamine effects' to 'ketamine dosing' = NOT a switch (same topic). Count each distinct topic transition.

indicators.name: unique_topic_domains
indicators.how_to_measure: Count distinct topical domains explored during the day. Categorize all activity into broad domains: programming/tech, health/medical, travel/planning, news/current-events, entertainment/music, shopping, food/restaurants, academic/research, social-media, personal-admin. Count how many distinct domains appear.

indicators.name: late_night_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the number of browsing activities (searches + page visits) occurring between 11:00 PM and 5:00 AM. If no activity in this window, count is 0.

indicators.name: early_morning_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count browsing activities occurring between 5:00 AM and 7:00 AM. Very early activity may indicate sleep disturbance. If no activity in this window, count is 0.

indicators.name: health_anxiety_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches and visits related to: health symptoms, medications, medical conditions, anxiety, stress management, mental health topics, drugs for mood/anxiety. Example: 'ketamine depression' or 'sleep problems' each count as 1.

indicators.name: erratic_browsing_episodes
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances of very rapid topic switching: 3+ different topics explored within a 5-minute window with no apparent connection. Each such episode counts as 1.

indicators.name: scattered_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count activities that appear disconnected from surrounding context - single searches or visits on a topic with no follow-up, sandwiched between unrelated activities. Each isolated, unfocused activity = 1.

indicators.name: search_refinement_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where a search is immediately followed (within 2 minutes) by a modified version of the same query, indicating difficulty formulating clear searches. Example: 'haskell fold' then 'haskell foldr' then 'foldr foldl difference' = 2 refinements.

indicators.name: distraction_site_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to entertainment and distraction sites: Reddit, YouTube (non-educational), Twitter/X, Instagram, Facebook, TikTok, entertainment news, gaming sites. Each page visit to these domains counts as 1. Note: Higher counts indicate LOWER self-regulation.

indicators.name: sustained_focus_sessions
indicators.how_to_measure: Count sessions where 5+ consecutive activities remain on the same topic for 15+ minutes. Example: 8 consecutive Haskell searches/docs over 25 minutes = 1 sustained session. Higher counts indicate better self-regulation.

indicators.name: topic_breadth_per_session
indicators.how_to_measure: For the main browsing session of the day, count how many distinct topics were explored. A topic is a coherent subject area (e.g., 'Haskell learning', 'travel planning Sicily', 'phone shopping'). High breadth indicates juggling many concerns.

indicators.name: incomplete_explorations
indicators.how_to_measure: Count topics that were briefly touched (1-2 activities only) then abandoned without apparent resolution. Example: single search about 'redis' with no follow-up = 1 incomplete exploration.

indicators.name: active_hours_span
indicators.how_to_measure: Record the number of hours between first and last browsing activity of the day as decimal hours (e.g., 10.5). If only one activity, record 0.

indicators.name: total_activity_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count the total number of browsing activities (searches + page visits) for the day. Each search query and each page visit counts as 1.

indicators.name: habitual_site_returns
indicators.how_to_measure: Count sites visited 3+ separate times during the day with gaps (30+ minutes) between visits. For each site meeting this criterion (e.g., Reddit visited at 9am, 11am, 3pm), add 1 to the count.

indicators.name: topic_return_cycles
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where a topic is visited, abandoned for a different topic, then returned to later. Example: ketamine research then phone plans then ketamine again = 1 return cycle. Each return to a previously-abandoned topic counts as 1.

indicators.name: deep_exploration_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances of sustained topic exploration: 6+ consecutive related activities spanning 20+ minutes on one subject. Example: extended Haskell learning session with multiple documentation pages and code examples = 1 deep exploration.

indicators.name: longest_topic_duration_minutes
indicators.how_to_measure: Identify the longest continuous exploration of a single topic and record its duration in minutes. Measure from first to last activity on that topic before switching away. Report the maximum duration observed for any topic.

indicators.name: escape_behavior_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count instances where work/technical browsing (documentation, code, professional tools) is abruptly interrupted (within 3 minutes) by entertainment or unrelated content (Reddit, YouTube, random browsing). Each work-to-escape transition = 1.

indicators.name: work_to_distraction_switches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count transitions from work-related content (documentation, code, professional searches) directly to distraction content (social media, entertainment, unrelated browsing). Each work-to-distraction transition = 1.

indicators.name: curiosity_tangent_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches/visits that appear to be pure curiosity with no practical purpose: Wikipedia rabbit holes, 'what is [random topic]' queries, exploring unrelated interesting subjects (e.g., 'williams syndrome', 'Occia gens', random historical topics). Each tangent = 1.

indicators.name: entertainment_seeking_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits seeking entertainment/stimulation: YouTube music videos, streaming content, music searches (artist names, song titles), social media browsing for fun, game-related content. Each entertainment-seeking visit = 1.

indicators.name: sub_minute_switches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count topic switches occurring within 60 seconds of the previous activity. Check timestamps: if activity at 10:01 is a different topic than activity at 10:00, count as 1. Each sub-minute topic switch = 1.

indicators.name: micro_exploration_count
indicators.how_to_measure: Count topics explored for less than 2 minutes before abandonment. If a topic appears at 10:00 and a different topic appears at 10:01, the first topic was a micro-exploration. Each such abandoned topic = 1.

indicators.name: question_based_searches
indicators.how_to_measure: Count searches phrased as questions or seeking basic understanding: queries containing 'what is', 'how to', 'why', 'tutorial', 'guide', 'explained', 'vs', or 'difference between'. Each qualifying search = 1.

indicators.name: search_variation_sequences
indicators.how_to_measure: Count sequences where the same concept is searched 3+ times with variations within 10 minutes, indicating uncertainty. Example: 'auth0' then 'auth0 vs okta' then 'auth0 pricing' then 'auth0 alternatives' = 1 sequence.

indicators.name: social_platform_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to notification-driven social/communication platforms: Twitter/X, Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, Slack, Discord, WhatsApp Web, Telegram, email services (Gmail, Outlook). Each visit = 1. Do NOT count Reddit or HackerNews here.

indicators.name: news_aggregator_visits
indicators.how_to_measure: Count visits to news and content aggregators: HackerNews, Reddit (front page or any subreddit), Google News, tech news sites (Techmeme, Ars Technica), general news websites (CNN, BBC, NYT). Each visit = 1.

indicators.name: focused_work_sessions
indicators.how_to_measure: Count browsing sessions (separated by 30+ minute gaps) where NO distraction sites (Reddit, Twitter, YouTube entertainment, Instagram, Facebook, news sites) were visited throughout the session. Each distraction-free session = 1.

indicators.name: documentation_focused_periods
indicators.how_to_measure: Count periods of 30+ minutes where browsing stayed primarily on documentation sites, reference materials, or focused work tools (GitHub, Stack Overflow for research, official docs) without visiting entertainment/social sites. Each such period = 1.
